item.title: Mario Kart World Is Now Japan's Fastest-Selling Mario Kart Game
item.content:encoded:
Mario Kart World has reached a new sales milestone in Japan, making it the series' fastest-selling game in that country to date.

According to sales data analyst pierre485 over on Bluesky, Mario Kart World has passed the 2.5 million sales mark in Japan, a milestone it took the game 29 weeks to reach.

That might sound like a long time, but according to pierre485's data, Mario Kart Wii took around 89 weeks (that's more than a year, by the way) to hit the same figure, so Mario Kart World's achievement should be a little more impressive in that context.

Mario Kart World is, according to pierre485's figures, also the fastest-selling Nintendo Switch 2 game, as well as the best-selling game of 2025 altogether. Remember, this data applies specifically to Japan and not to the rest of the world.

Back in November, Nintendo revealed that Mario Kart World was nearing the 10 million sales mark, with fellow Nintendo Switch 2 exclusive Donkey Kong Bananza sitting at a very respectable 3.5 million at that time. It's not clear whether this new data has helped the game cross that line; we'll likely find out when Nintendo next announces its financials.

Indeed, it's been a strong year for the Switch 2 on the whole. Back in August, it was revealed that the console had managed to pass 6 million sales, taking under two months to do so, and that Nintendo's revenue soared as a result (as you'd expect with the release of a successful new piece of hardware).

The console's lineup will be bolstered in the coming year by the likes of Phasmophobia and smash hit adventure Dispatch, as well as Nintendo's own Pokemon Pokopia, which, if my own (very amateur) predictions are correct, will make roughly all of the money that exists in the world right now. Mario Kart being Mario Kart, I'd expect World sales to trundle along nicely as well.

You can check out Mario Kart World right now exclusively on Nintendo Switch 2. Stay tuned for more.

item.title: Phasmophobia 1.0 Coming in 2026, "Horror 2.0" Still On the Cards
item.content:encoded:
Kinetic Games has provided a sneak peek at what 2026 will hold for ghost-hunting horror game Phasmophobia, and the studio is promising that the game's long-awaited 1.0 release is coming next year, plus lots more.

In a development preview posted on the official Kinetic website (on Christmas Day, of all days!), the studio confirms that Phasmophobia 1.0 is scheduled for next year, although the developer stops short of providing a more specific release window.

Additionally, "what was previously known as Horror 2.0" will also be arriving alongside the full release, bringing with it "a host of new scares and surprises" that should give "even the most seasoned Ghost Hunter" a run for their money.

In addition to the 1.0 release, Phasmophobia is also getting a brand new character creator next year, which will allow you to "customize your Ghost Hunter in-game with free cosmetics and different looks". You can also look forward to an animation overhaul that's aimed at creating a more immersive gameplay experience through increased realism of movement.

A rework for Phasmophobia's Tanglewood Drive map is also on the way, and while Kinetic acknowledges that the announcement of the map's rework was met with "a bit of trepidation", the studio says it hopes its work on the Bleasdale and Grafton Farmhouse map reworks will reassure players that the aim is to "level up the location".

All of this is, of course, alongside the Nintendo Switch 2 port of the game that Kinetic announced back in December, as well as the Phasmophobia movie that's currently in development at horror production studio Blumhouse. Suffice it to say that it's a good time to be a Phasmophobia fan (or perhaps that should be "phan").

If you aren't familiar with Phasmophobia, it's a multiplayer ghost-hunting horror game in which the goal is to find and document various paranormal phenomena haunting a range of different maps. You'll use tools and observation to figure out what's haunting where, then report back to your teammates.

Phasmophobia is available now for PC, PlayStation 5, and Xbox Series X|S, and a version of the game is heading to Switch 2 as well (presumably at around the same time as the 1.0 launch). Stay tuned for more.
